title: The ultimate guide to OKRs | Christina Wodtke (Stanford)
key_insights: OKRs are a vitamin, not medicine - they work best for companies that already have their fundamentals together
The atomic unit of OKRs is answering 'What am I doing this week to get closer to our goals?'
Start OKR implementation with your best performing team, not struggling teams
Keep OKR planning fast - ideally one week maximum, focus on execution over perfection
Use the 'how do we know?' question to derive key results from objectives
Weekly status emails with confidence levels create powerful learning cycles
Product managers must understand business fundamentals, not just user experience
Physical proximity and visual collaboration tools significantly improve team innovation

guest_background.current_role: Lecturer at Stanford, Author, and Product Management Consultant

memorable_quotes: OKRs are more of a vitamin, they're not a medicine. If you take OKRs and you're like, 'Oh, this will fix everything that's wrong with you.' No, that's not going to happen.
What am I doing this week to get closer to our goals? If you could answer that question, you could give up all the OKR stuff
Product sense is intuition, intuition is compressed experience, compressed experience comes from having lots of experience.
recommended_for: Anyone struggling with team focus and alignment
summary: Christina Wodtke, Stanford lecturer and OKR expert, provides a comprehensive guide to implementing effective OKR processes, emphasizing that OKRs work best as accelerators for already-functional teams rather than fixes for broken organizations. The episode offers practical frameworks for OKR implementation, common pitfalls to avoid, and insights on product management fundamentals.
